newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Arab League head gives UN council Lockerbie letter.
newsitem.headline: Arab League head gives UN council Lockerbie letter.

text.p: The secretary-general of the Arab League formally proposed on Thursday that two Libyans indicted in the 1988 Lockerbie Pan Am bombing be tried by Scottish judges under Scottish law in a neutral country.

Secretary-General Ahmed Esmat Abdel Meguid told Reuters he sent the proposal to the Security Council president in a letter signed by himself and Salim Ahmed Salim of Tanzania, secretary-general of the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), which approved the move at a summit meeting early this month.

Abdel Meguid, attending a U.N. Earth Summit reviewing environmental progress in the past five years, said the OAU had proposed "a trial by Scottish judges, the application of Scottish law and the site is to be decided upon."

Two alleged Libyan intelligence agents have been indicted in Britain and the United States in connection with the December 1988 mid-air bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over the Scottish village of Lockerbie that killed 270 people, including 11 on the ground. Libya has been under U.N. sanctions since 1992 for failing to hand the two over for trial in Britain or the United States.

Libya, backed by the Arab League and the OAU, has proposed that they be tried by Scottish judges under Scottish law but in some other country. London and Washington have rejected this as unacceptable.

Abdel Meguid, a former foreign minister of Egypt, said the OAU decision was "another sign of the flexibility shown by the Arab countries and the African countries to try to put an end to this very tragic situation."
